--- title: "Effect Modification Analysis within the Propensity score Framework" author: "Mohammad Ehsanul Karim" format: html: toc: true number-sections: true editor: visual execute: cache: true --- ## Simulation First, we need to install the R package `simcausal`, which can be obtained from GitHub: ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_4e6f515dd57a5656dc90caf5bab54e67'} ```{.r .cell-code} devtools::install_github('osofr/simcausal', build_vignettes = FALSE) ``` ::: We will use the following data-generation model: ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-3_3ce556834b402725aeb1d9fdd5044354'} ```{.r .cell-code} require(simcausal) D <- DAG.empty() D <- D + node("age", distr = "rnorm", mean = 2, sd = 4) + node("gender", distr = "rbern", prob = plogis(4)) + node("education", distr = "rbern", prob = plogis(3 + 5* age)) + node("diet", distr = "rbern", prob = plogis(1 -3 * education)) + node("income", distr = "rbern", prob = plogis(2 - 5 * education - 4 * age)) + node("smoking", distr = "rbern", prob = plogis(1 + 1.2 * gender + 2 * age)) + node("hypertension", distr = "rbern", prob = plogis(1 + log(3) * diet + log(1.3) * age + log(3.5) * smoking + log(0.5) * gender)) Dset <- set.DAG(D) plotDAG(Dset) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](chapter_07_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: We can now generate an example dataset: ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-4_60641942739348b2ae45589a9692371c'} ```{.r .cell-code} Obs.Data <- sim(DAG = Dset, n = 50000, rndseed = 123) Obs.Data$smoking <- as.character(Obs.Data$smoking) Obs.Data$income <- as.factor(Obs.Data$income) Obs.Data$income <- relevel(Obs.Data$income, ref = "1") ``` ::: Sample data from the hypothetical example of association between hypertension and smoking, where other variables such as income, age \[centered\], gender, education and diet also plays a role in the data generation process. ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-5_de9a2919738abdf0f1b85faab7bc878c'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` age gender education diet income smoking hypertension 34901 12.288936 1 1 1 0 1 1 149 10.400436 1 1 0 0 1 1 10060 2.991820 1 1 0 0 1 0 22220 -4.311952 0 0 0 1 0 1 9979 -6.435549 0 0 0 1 0 1 ``` ::: ::: ## Effect measure assessment via adding interaction term Below, we estimate a logistic regression model to assess whether the effect of smoking (the exposure) on hypertension is modified by income. The covariates age and gender are confounders. ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-6_26516b1d25716f598a1bd19979418142'} ```{.r .cell-code} fit.w.em <- glm(hypertension ~ smoking * income + age + gender, family = binomial(link = "logit"), data = Obs.Data) require(jtools) results.model <- summ(fit.w.em, model.info = FALSE, model.fit = FALSE, exp = TRUE) results.model ``` ::: {.cell-output-display}
exp(Est.) 2.5% 97.5% z val. p
(Intercept) 5.46 4.37 6.82 14.97 0.00
smoking1 2.93 2.60 3.30 17.69 0.00
income0 0.48 0.41 0.57 -8.28 0.00
age 1.29 1.27 1.31 36.77 0.00
gender 0.54 0.43 0.67 -5.55 0.00
smoking1:income0 1.27 1.04 1.56 2.33 0.02
Standard errors: MLE
::: ::: The interaction term in `results.model` is statistically significant. ### Presentation of effect measures {.unnumbered} We can generate a summary report from aforementioned effect modification analysis. The table below depicts the adjusted odds ratios for income levels (`high = 0`, and `low = 1`) ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-7_453ab8129178300106059a46d4b1573d'} ```{.r .cell-code} require(interactionR) em.object <- interactionR(fit.w.em, exposure_names = c("income0", "smoking1"), ci.type = "mover", ci.level = 0.95, em = TRUE, recode = FALSE) em.object$dframe[,1:4] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Measures Estimates CI.ll CI.ul 1 OR00 1.0000000 NA NA 2 OR01 2.9301604 2.6010653 3.3008937 3 OR10 0.4832932 0.4068652 0.5740780 4 OR11 1.7997639 1.6334908 1.9829619 5 OR(smoking1 on outcome [income0==0] 2.9301604 2.6010653 3.3008937 6 OR(smoking1 on outcome [income0==1] 3.7239584 3.1434919 4.4116118 7 Multiplicative scale 1.2709060 1.0385052 1.5553143 8 RERI -0.6136898 -0.9754808 -0.2905171 ``` ::: ::: ## Effect measure assessment via stratified approach This approach involves estimating a regression model in different strata of the effect modifier `income`: ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-8_0ee5f4e2e89d985b84204c47d01cd2e6'} ```{.r .cell-code} fit.income1 <- glm(hypertension ~ smoking + age + gender, family = binomial(link = "logit"), data = subset(Obs.Data, income == 1)) fit.income0 <- glm(hypertension ~ smoking + age + gender, family=binomial(link = "logit"), data= subset(Obs.Data, income == 0)) ``` ::: The table below summarizes the adjusted odds ratios for smoking across the different income levels (`low = 1`, and `high = 0`) as obtained using the stratified approach. ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-9_411e399494dcefe15ba2c36968659b4e'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Value of income exp(Est.) 2.5% 97.5% z val. p [1,] 1 3.066878 2.707961 3.473366 17.64728 1.067842e-69 [2,] 0 3.590260 3.023124 4.263792 14.57113 4.287200e-48 ``` ::: ::: Note that we can obtain the same results by estimating a regression model with an interaction term between the modifier and all covariates: ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-10_2b6d7ed6eb4db32c4519a1727d68d476'} ```{.r .cell-code} fit.all.int <- glm(hypertension ~ income * (smoking + age + gender), family = binomial(link = "logit"), data = Obs.Data) # Odds ratio for smoking in individuals with low income exp(coef(fit.all.int)["smoking1"]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` smoking1 3.066878 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Odds ratio for smoking in individuals with high income exp(coef(fit.all.int)["smoking1"] + coef(fit.all.int)["income0:smoking1"]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` smoking1 3.59026 ``` ::: ::: ## Interaction Assessment of interaction between smoking and income. We estimate a logistic regression model where - Outcome: `hypertension` - Exposure variables: `smoking` and `income` - Confounders: `age`, `gender`, and `education` An interaction term of smoking and income is added. ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-11_d58274c1f42a4ecbb607d026b08d89ce'} ```{.r .cell-code} fit.w.int <- glm(hypertension ~ smoking * income + age + gender + education, family = binomial(link = "logit"), data = Obs.Data) results.int.model <- summ(fit.w.int, model.info = FALSE, model.fit = FALSE, exp = TRUE) results.int.model$coeftable ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` exp(Est.) 2.5% 97.5% z val. p (Intercept) 5.6937765 4.5570175 7.1141027 15.3077121 6.791105e-53 smoking1 3.3452459 2.9505339 3.7927612 18.8503257 2.920389e-79 income0 1.0908060 0.8506311 1.3987941 0.6849951 4.933470e-01 age 1.2981524 1.2804814 1.3160673 37.3150071 9.371499e-305 gender 0.5366777 0.4313229 0.6677666 -5.5815569 2.383750e-08 education 0.4233969 0.3502014 0.5118909 -8.8749618 6.995745e-19 smoking1:income0 1.1022535 0.8968615 1.3546825 0.9253438 3.547871e-01 ``` ::: ::: The interaction term between income and smoking is, however, not statistically significant. ### Presentation of effect measures {.unnumbered} ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-12_aa7c2f312d0d0a381fb96b3a0d12be9e'} ```{.r .cell-code} int.object = interactionR(fit.w.int, exposure_names = c("smoking1", "income0"), ci.type = "mover", ci.level = 0.95, em = FALSE, recode = FALSE) ``` ::: Summary report from an interaction analysis when investigating association between two exposure variables (smoking and income) and hypertension. Below, `CI.ll` and `CI.ul` depict the lower and upper limits of the 95 percent confidence intervals, `OR11` = $OR_{A = 1, M = 1}$ , `OR10` = $OR_{A = 1}$, `OR01` = $OR_{M = 1}$ and `OR00` captures the reference. ::: {#tbl-effint .cell tbl-cap='Summary report from an interaction analysis when investigating association between two exposure variables (smoking and income) and hypertension.' hash='chapter_07_cache/html/tbl-effint_3cbc1f5613d7e37b452194c1010d20fa'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Measures Estimates CI.ll CI.ul 1 OR00 1.0000000 NA NA 2 OR01 1.0908060 0.850631061 1.3987941 3 OR10 3.3452459 2.950533888 3.7927612 4 OR11 4.0221386 3.287881778 4.9203713 5 OR(income0 on outcome [smoking1==0] 1.0908060 0.850631061 1.3987941 6 OR(income0 on outcome [smoking1==1] 1.2023447 0.997265811 1.4495962 7 OR(smoking1 on outcome [income0==0] 3.3452459 2.950533888 3.7927612 8 OR(smoking1 on outcome [income0==1] 3.6873089 3.112335708 4.3685026 9 Multiplicative scale 1.1022535 0.896861546 1.3546825 10 RERI 0.5860867 0.029944164 1.2657133 11 AP 0.1457152 -0.004274684 0.2598376 12 SI 1.2405887 1.008364517 1.5262937 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-14_6be470da07def7673090d4a7234583ca'} ```{.r .cell-code} # test run with additive model Obs.Data$smoking <- as.numeric(as.character(Obs.Data$smoking)) Obs.Data$income <- as.numeric(as.character(Obs.Data$income)) fit.w.int.add <- glm(hypertension ~ smoking * income + age + gender + education, family=gaussian(link = "identity"), data=Obs.Data) sim_slopes(fit.w.int.add, pred = smoking, modx = income, exp = TRUE, robust = TRUE, confint = TRUE, data = Obs.Dat) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` JOHNSON-NEYMAN INTERVAL When income is INSIDE the interval [-3.27, 16.87], the slope of smoking is p < .05. Note: The range of observed values of income is [0.00, 1.00] SIMPLE SLOPES ANALYSIS Slope of smoking when income = 0.00 (0): Est. S.E. 2.5% 97.5% t val. p ------ ------ ------ ------- -------- ------ 0.25 0.02 1.24 1.34 12.76 0.00 Slope of smoking when income = 1.00 (1): Est. S.E. 2.5% 97.5% t val. p ------ ------ ------ ------- -------- ------ 0.28 0.01 1.30 1.34 34.53 0.00 ``` ::: ::: ## Step-by-Step Guideline for Practitioners regarding Implementation ### Propensity score matching approaches #### Stratified approach with exact matching within subgroups {.unnumbered} ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-15_f9d73806a40c9994aac4883760c6be3d'} ```{.r .cell-code} # For income = 0 require(MatchIt) set.seed(123) Obs.Data <- sim(DAG = Dset, n = 5000, rndseed = 123) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` simulating observed dataset from the DAG object ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} match.income.0 <- matchit(smoking ~ age + gender, data = subset(Obs.Data, income == 0), method = "full", distance = "glm", link = "logit") data.income.0 <- match.data(match.income.0) ``` ::: Below, we draw a sample from the high-income group based on the hypothetical example of an association between hypertension and smoking. Here age \[centered\], gender, education, and diet are covariates. ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-16_3cac5af3dfeabf4573607d42bf9bb389'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` age gender education diet income smoking hypertension distance 657 6.0810120 0 1 1 0 1 1 0.9999874 4932 1.6109860 1 1 0 0 1 0 0.9943155 252 -0.2475055 1 1 1 0 0 1 0.8525107 2693 -0.2511048 1 1 0 0 1 1 0.8516785 1646 -0.2836155 1 0 1 0 1 1 0.8439843 weights subclass 657 1.00000000 36 4932 1.00000000 50 252 0.03296089 25 2693 1.00000000 25 1646 1.00000000 4 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-17_0230b583fdfbdd8bd4179bcd4ed70530'} ```{.r .cell-code} # For income = 1 match.income.1 <- matchit(smoking ~ age + gender, data = subset(Obs.Data, income == 1), method = "full", distance = "glm", link = "logit") data.income.1 <- match.data(match.income.1) ``` ::: ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-18_217ae2d78fa351e1a7ecff216085fc59'} ```{.r .cell-code} # Treatment effect estimation fit.income.0 <- glm(hypertension ~ smoking + age + gender, data = data.income.0, weights = weights, family = binomial("logit")) fit.income.1 <- glm(hypertension ~ smoking + age + gender, data = data.income.1, weights = weights, family = binomial("logit")) # Robust variance calculation require(jtools) fit.nexp.adj.res1 <- summ(fit.income.1, robust = TRUE, cluster = "subclass", model.info = FALSE, model.fit = FALSE, confint = TRUE) fit.nexp.adj.res0 <- summ(fit.income.0, robust = TRUE, cluster = "subclass", model.info = FALSE, model.fit = FALSE, confint = TRUE) ``` ::: ::: {#tbl-stratified-approach .cell tbl-cap='Subgroup-specific treatment effect estimates (expressed in log-OR) from the hypothetical example using the stratified approach.' hash='chapter_07_cache/html/tbl-stratified-approach_f38bc55d704f3239264062fbba683127'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Value of income Est. 2.5% 97.5% z val. p [1,] 0 3.739945 -37.5789304 45.058820 0.1774046 8.591906e-01 [2,] 1 1.394520 0.9418774 1.847163 6.0383367 1.557109e-09 ``` ::: ::: #### Joint approach without exact matching within subgroups {.unnumbered} ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-20_b29d729ecf069870b0c28aab6da4c456'} ```{.r .cell-code} ps.formula <- as.formula("smoking ~ age + gender + income") match.obj.j <- matchit(ps.formula, data = Obs.Data, method = "full", distance = "glm", link = "logit") match.data.j <- match.data(match.obj.j) ``` ::: ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-21_b15e1a6175a8b97c3455e334c98bb0c3'} ```{.r .cell-code} fit.joint.no.exact <- glm(hypertension ~ smoking*income + age + gender, data = match.data.j, weights = weights, family = binomial("logit")) require(interactions) nem.nexp.adj.res <- sim_slopes(fit.joint.no.exact, pred = smoking, modx = income, robust = "HC1", cluster = "subclass", johnson_neyman = TRUE, confint = TRUE, data = match.data.j) ``` ::: ::: {#tbl-joint-approach .cell tbl-cap='Subgroup-specific treatment effect estimates (expressed in log-OR) from the hypothetical example using the joint approach.' hash='chapter_07_cache/html/tbl-joint-approach_85d94127960d3ee7d1a9dc59252537d7'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Value of income Est. S.E. 2.5% 97.5% z val. p 1 0 3.854853 1.0033297 1.8883628 5.821343 3.842060 1.220060e-04 2 1 1.401206 0.2805318 0.8513733 1.951038 4.994819 5.889087e-07 ``` ::: :::
